text: well I'm not convinced that you can
describe it as a good war in the first
place uh though we love to and uh
documentary makers in the United States
particularly like to represent uh World
War II as uh a kind of morality play a
contest between uh good and evil uh
foret getting conveniently that the war
was waged
principally uh in its latter phase by
the Soviet Union against Nazi Germany
that is where the preponderance of the
fighting occurred on the Eastern front
and the Soviet Union though it was
Allied to the Western democracies was
really as abhorent a totalitarian regime
uh as the others that we were fighting
against and it had of course begun the
war in 1939 before the United States
became became involved on the same side
as as Nazi Germany so in the War of the
World I try to make it clear that this
is extremely hard to take seriously as a
morality play it was a a horrible event
which could only be one uh by using the
worst possible uh tactics that had been
pioneered by the Axis powers for example
uh it was only possible to win World War
II by bombing civilians uh this is an
extremely efficient way of killing
people uh it was a way of killing people
that had been denounced by Western
leaders in the 1930s but it was
wholeheartedly embraced by them after
the war had begun and its ultimate
product was the destruction of Hiroshima
and Nagasaki by atomic weapons it's hard
to see this as a a good war in any
really meaningful sense except that it
had a good outcome compared with the old
available alternative outcome uh of an
access Victory and I I'm I'm certain
that that would have produced a worse
world than the world that that we uh we
inherited in 1945 that is as much as I
think one can say about World War II
subsequent Wars actually may have better
claims the Cold War uh was a much better
War uh than World War II in in in two
respects firstly the issues were far
more clear-cut uh the choice between uh
Freedom with all its uh disadvantages
and
complexities and totalitarian Comm rule
was a clear-cut choice and it is obvious
which the right side was although there
is no question that the United States
and its allies made many many moral
compromises uh in order to win the Cold
War it was nevertheless the right side
to be on and I felt that passionately in
the last decade of the Cold War when I
was coming of age politically uh and it
must be said that not many of my
contemporaries at Oxford in the early
1980s saw as clearly as I think I saw
saw which side was the right side in the
Cold War the other good thing about the
Cold War was that relatively few people
died uh compared with World War II of
course there was violence and most of it
happened in the third world uh it wasn't
quite the long pieace that some people
uh call it but it was certainly
preferable to a fullblown nuclear war so
I'm in that sense a fan of the Cold
War
